While most of the time anxiety disorders develop in adolescence, I’ve the unfortunate position wherein I’ve simply always been like this. I don’t actually know what it means to feel or live ‘normally’.
The way I explain it to people who don’t understand is this: my brain sees things that are safe and mistakes them for being dangerous. That leaves me to deal with the messy fight or flight response in situations where I can’t do either.
My general anxiety disorder makes me afraid of:
Eye contact. Phone calls. Talking to people. Text messaging. Knocking on doors. Buildings, people, or situations I am unfamiliar with. Physical contact. Being too loud. Doing anything, even the smallest thing, wrong (like, I’m afraid to pour my own mother a bowl of cereal because I might get the ratio of milk to cereal wrong). I freeze when there’s something I’m not absolutely sure how to go about doing.
See, that adrenaline makes thought just about impossible. I can’t think my way out of the situation, because my brain shuts down. It’s preparing for a physical battle for my life when it shouldn’t be.
I’m a bit obsessive compulsive, but not cleanliness- ocd takes a lot of different forms- and since it doesn’t usually hinder me, it’s not ocd. Not a disorder.
I have athropodophobia, the intense, irrational fear of anything with an exoskeleton (yes, crabs and lobsters too, no, spiders aren’t the worst, crickets and grasshoppers are) as well as necrophobia, the fear of dead bodies (so it actually makes it worse if I kill the bugs scaring me).
I also get panic attacks, my most frequent symptoms being the same as a heart attack, which sucks but I’m honestly used to it.

Because of all this I can feel really embarrassed about myself. I’m a twenty year old who gets fired from jobs because I freeze at the simplest of things, can’t talk to costumers or anyone else, has to be shown exactly what to do as though I’m a child, and cries at the sight of a bug. It’s easy to get down about it, and it does get to me. But hey. I’m trying to do better, and that’s okay.

So you described selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) wrong. With depression, a lack of serotonin is often present. Reuptakes are sensors in the preceding neuron which, when binded to, tell it to stop releasing that neurotransmitter. So by inhibiting the reuptake, more serotonin is allowed to bounce around in the synapse and bind to the receptors it should.

Opioid addicts claim they would take opioid withdrawal a million times over benzo withdrawal.

Unless you absolutely have to take them I would suggest trying literally anything else.

I was diagnosed with Generalized Anxiety Disorder in 2003. I was fresh out of HS, where I was a very outgoing and social person. Anxiety is debilitating. People look at you like you're either crazy, or on drugs. I was on Paxil for something like 10 years. I finally learned to somewhat control it by learning what triggers my attacks (driving at night, caffeine mainly, but other small things as well), and I found that for some reason, the sound of my mother's voice really helps me through a severe attack. All I have to do is call her up and she knows what to do lol. I've also taken up painting and/or drawing for those crappy middle-of-the-night attacks that like to creep up on me for no reason. I've managed to not have to take any medication for my anxiety since 2013. Everybody deals with anxiety differently but that's how I deal with mine if it helps anybody. It is helpful to know that I'm not the only one in the world going through it, because I don't know about anybody else but when I was diagnosed and even up to this day I feel like the most alone person in the world when I'm having an attack.

Very informative and concise rundown. I have anxiety attributed to an old back injury and pinched nerve/nerves which pretty much hurt all the time, but it does vary. Pinched nerves="nerve"ousness as I've experienced it, but also can cause other strange neurological symptoms such as difficulty in moving and slurred speech. It can be really horrible when people think you're drunk when you haven't been drinking by unsteady movements and the slurring. Anti inflammatories help tremendously alongisde inversion therapy (hanging upside down.) Relaxing the spine will typically and temporarily relieve my anxiety to a degree, but also the troubles with speech and movement. Ultimately, my body responds with adrenaline (since I won't take prescription painkillers on principle) which comes with it's own set of problems... including anxiety! So that's just me, but it hopefully adds another (strictly subjective) facet to the reasons explained in the video.
